text: Indonesia will begin moving its capital
from Jakarta to the island of Borneo
president Joko Widodo announced in late
august construction is scheduled to
start in 2021 and government offices
will relocate to the new city in phases
from 2024 along with as many as 1.5
million employees and their families the
relocation will cost an estimated thirty
three billion dollars spread over ten
years all of this begs the question
what's wrong with Jakarta Amir hosts
children and welcome the Caspian report

believe it or not the idea to move the
Indonesian capital has been a topic of
discussion since the inception of the
state in fact in 1957 Indonesia's first
president Sukarno
envisioned a small city of palangka raya
as the capital forum appear window which
was a proposed Confederation that
included Indonesia Malaysia and the
Philippines
the plan never materialized and instead
the seat of the Indonesian government
shifted from island to island because it
was difficult to determine the exact
seat of power eventually in 1964 sukarno
settled for Jakarta as the official
capital over the decades Jakarta grew to
a city of 10 million or 30 million when
accounting those in its greater
metropolitan area while the alternative
capital Palin Korea remained a sleepy
town of some 270,000 people since 2010
however some policy makers have started
to revive the memory of Palin Korea as
the capital of Indonesia but all
proposals kept
failing then in April 2000 nineteen the
newly reelected president Joko Widodo
also known as Yoko V proposed a thirty
three billion dollar project to relocate
the capital to another city by 2020 for
what said his proposal apart is the
indicated timeline and budget also Yoko
V stated that the relocation of the new
capital would be an administrative
operation but only the government and
its employees shifting places Jakarta
will remain the economic epicentre of
the nation no government can change
those market forces since the
announcement several cities have been
pitched as the next capital such as
jungle in West Java sedan veneer upon in
South Sulawesi and topping the list
Palin Korea in Borneo but before we get
ahead of ourselves let's look at
everything that is wrong with the
current capital for most Jakarta is a
typical Asian mega city sinking under
the weight of its own dysfunction
literally so every year the city sinks
by an average of 17 centimeters due to
rising sea levels and poor management of
groundwater extraction you see Jakarta
suffers from a subsidence crisis only
four percent of the city's wastewater is
treated this causes massive pollution to
nearby rivers and forces people to
extract their clean water from
underground rendering the building atop
susceptible to collapse climate change
and rising sea levels is another factor
that contributes to the sinking of
Jakarta for over a decade the government
has been in a race against the sea a
steady stream of floods has devastated
homes and vehicles and businesses all
over the capital some of those floods
have even been deadly the government has
considered all sorts of proposals to
stop the flooding including one to
construct a giant wall in the sea now
however the state has come to terms that
it just might be losing the fight
against nature already as much as 40
percent of Jakarta sits below sea level
by 2050 up to 95% of North Jakarta
currently home to 1.4 million people is
expected to submerge by that time the
overcrowded metropolitan area of Jakarta
is also expected to grow from nearly 30
million to 30 5.6 million making it the
world's biggest city but there's only so
much a city can handle until its
infrastructure caves in with 3.5 million
daily commuters Jakarta is infamous for
its endemic traffic with congestion
costing the government nearly 7 billion
dollars a year in lost productivity over
the years the government has invested
tens of billions of dollars to improve
the infrastructure but it has thus far
little to show for with issues such as
traffic congestion pollution
overpopulation and flooding it's no
wonder that the government feels the
urgency and temptation to move the
capital however environmental concern is
only part of the motive for the
relocation the Republic of Indonesia is
a remarkably vast and diverse country
with more than 17,000 islands stretching
for more than 5,000 kilometers that's
roughly the distance from Iceland to
Azerbaijan marking the extreme corners
of the European continent it's a
testament to the resolve of Indonesian
policymakers that they managed to unify
such a domain considering the hundreds
of different ethnic cultural and
religious backgrounds maintaining that
unity has always been the government's
top priority plus the idea is that
moving the capital away from Jaffa
Island would encourage new avenues for
investment in other places from an
economic lens Indonesia has long sought
to develop new centers of growth outside
the islands of Java and Sumatra which
separately generate 58 percent and 20
percent of the country's GDP
respectively the key is to move the
capital to an existing city where the
local economy can benefit from the
relocation but it cannot be too far away
from Jakarta by these criteria
palangka raya in borneo the alternative
capital in the 1960s is a good fit the
city said some 900 kilometers to the
northeast of jakarta in central
kalimantan which is the indonesian part
of borneo
although java never revealed the exact
location or the name of the new capital
government officials did state that the
site will be somewhere in Borneo if
pollen Korea does turn out to be the new
capital it will bring forth its own set
of problems
Borneo which is shared by three nations
suffers from its own pollution and land
subsidence issues the once majestic
rainforests of Borneo have withered
considerably over the decades illegal
logging and deliberate burning have
destroyed 1/3 of the tropical
rainforests deforestation has made more
space available for oil palm plantations
but it has also released high amounts of
carbon dioxide into the atmosphere so
the poor air quality in Jakarta is
prevalent in Borneo as well obeyed to a
lesser degree furthermore Indonesia's
new capital would take up about 30,000
hectare with housing to be constructed
for 900,000 to 1.5 million people mostly
government employees and their families
the sudden arrival of so many people
would endanger the remaining forests and
wildlife but it would also raise carbon
emissions and contribute to the sinking
of the area by all accounts the whole
capital relocation project seems poorly
thought out for jokowi however it makes
perfect sense he came to office on the
promise of unity and infrastructure
during Joey's first term the state spent
about 350 billion dollars on various
infrastructure projects with another 412
billion dollars planned for the next
five years
shifting the capital to another area
would help strengthen the sense of unity
in the country thereby fulfilling his
campaign promises however before
relocation can proceed Jacobi's
administrator
we'll have to obtain the necessary
funding the government for instance only
plans to fund up to 19% of the total
cost with the remainder being funded by
a mix of state-owned and private firms
in his announcement
jokowi mentioned that the burden hasn't
become too heavy on Jakarta as the
center of government finance trade and
services that might be true but
relocating the capital will in no way
address any of Jakarta's complications
just because the government moves to
another city doesn't mean that
established businesses will simply pack
up and follow suit there is no incentive
for them to do so
Jakarta will keep growing regardless of
the presence of government offices
traffic congestion pollution
overpopulation and rising sea levels
will all persist into the future the
residents of Jakarta will all remain and
the problems they face will still be
there
